bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 11, 1900

div1.p: Reed settles into camp life, and observes a malaria case. He discusses finances, and notes that Carroll has returned to Cuba from the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, November 11, 1900
div1.opener:
Give old
Doogs a pat
on the back
for me.
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba,
Novr 11th 1900-
My precious wifie;
div1.p:
Both
of your darling letters
came on yesterday Saturday.
I suppose that the one written
on Saturday must have just
missed Monday's boat
leaving Tampa at 10 P.M.
The best way, I think after
all, is for you to write
just when you get ready
and feel like doing so. The
letter written Wednesday
7th reached me Saturday
the 10th. I hope that mine
mailed on Wednesday reached
you as soon- If so, you found
out that I didn't have the
smoothest trip imaginable-
I did feel a little bit knocked
out when I got here, but
am alright now- Have
my usual appetite and
have gotten back in the
old Traces once more- I
found Steward Neate al-
most sick from malarial
fever; but having found
the parasite in his blood.
I have had him dose himself
heavily with quinine, and he
is alright again- What an
oomsey you are, to invest
in a toy-bird! and to try
to fool cricket with it? How
did you catch the little bird?
By springling salt on his
trail? So you saw Miss Lou
Bettens? What was she doing
in Washington? Did she have
her fine boys with her? I only
wish you could see the Stark
boys. They are too cute for
anything! It strikes me that
Johnnie Moore's bill of #44.25
was a good sized one, unless
it included the lime: but
I think that was in his
last bill- Look at it and
see- I feel sure that I
had already paid for lime
and manure. Send that bill
to me- I would like to see
it- Of course, you have already
sent him a check for it-
I guess though that it is alright and
you need not send it- Monday
morning, Novr 12th- Dear me! I
have nearly overslept myself and
almost missed getting my
letter in the mail- I sat up read-
ing till 11 P.M. & hence didn't awake
as early as usual- The morning
is cloudy and much warmer
than it has been- Have just
received a telegram from Car-
roll at Matanzas, saying that
he will be at Havana by
noon. I will send my wagon
down for him. Am glad to have
him back as I want to put him
to work- Give Miss Mason my
love- Take good care of your
darling selves. Love also to Mrs.
D. & Miss Lucy- Write often- Kisses
& love for my precious babies-
